thinkers.name: Michael Levin
thinkers.context: Distinguished professor and Vannevar Bush chair in biology at Tufts University; director of Allen Discovery Center at Tufts; studies scaling of intelligence from molecular to organismal levels and implications for AI ethics.

thinkers.name: Alan Turing
thinkers.context: Recognized for understanding deep symmetry between self-creation of bodies and development of minds; research spanned AI and origin of order in embryonic chemical systems.

thinkers.name: John Steinbeck
thinkers.context: Quoted for views on individual creation and collective invention, used as counterpoint to discuss how all intelligences are inherently collective.

concepts.name: Diverse Intelligence
concepts.context: Central concept proposing that intelligence exists on a vast spectrum encompassing humans, AI, biological systems, and future hybrid forms deserving moral consideration.

concepts.name: Moral Worth
concepts.context: Quality attributed to agents capable of goal-directed problem-solving and suffering; basis for determining ethical obligations toward diverse intelligences.

concepts.name: Agency
concepts.context: Goal-directed problem-solving capacity present at multiple scales from molecular networks to organisms; critical for recognizing and relating to unconventional intelligences.

concepts.name: Consciousness
concepts.context: Proposed to exist on a continuum rather than as binary property; expansion of consciousness into diverse embodiments challenges traditional definitions.

concepts.name: Cognition
concepts.context: Present at multiple scales including molecular networks, cells, and organs; learning and problem-solving capacities exist throughout biological hierarchies.

concepts.name: Embodied Mind
concepts.context: Integration of physical form with mental processes; grounding of thought through interaction with environment; crucial for understanding different types of intelligence.

concepts.name: Self
concepts.context: Understood as dynamic process and collection of stories rather than fixed entity; maintained through commitment to shared goals across body components.

concepts.name: Self-Model
concepts.context: Collective commitment of cells to particular anatomical and developmental outcomes; enables body maintenance, resistance to cancer, and regeneration.

concepts.name: Compassion
concepts.context: Essential ethical capacity for relating to diverse intelligences; foundation for developing synthetic biosis and mutual flourishing across different beings.

concepts.name: Care
concepts.context: Proposed shift from instrumental questions about AI capabilities to ethical questions about caring for diverse intelligences and mutual benefit.

concepts.name: Cellular Collective Intelligence
concepts.context: Problem-solving and decision-making capacities of cells and tissues operating in physiological and anatomical spaces; analogous to studying alien minds.

concepts.name: Bioelectricity
concepts.context: Electrical signals passing through information-processing networks of all cells; component of 'cognitive glue' binding cells into unified selves.

concepts.name: Morphogenetic Pattern Memories
concepts.context: Bioelectrically stored information about anatomical layouts and structures; reprogrammable like neural memories; enable guided regeneration.

concepts.name: Plasticity
concepts.context: Ability to determine own story about structure, capabilities and goals; fundamental for evolutionary survival and adapting to novel embodiments.

concepts.name: Engrams
concepts.context: Biophysical traces in brain and body representing past experiences; constantly reinterpreted adaptively rather than faithfully retrieved.

concepts.name: Free Energy Principle
concepts.context: Universal principle governing how organisms maintain organization and minimize entropy through interaction with environment and learning.

concepts.name: Emergence
concepts.context: Arising of novel properties and organizational levels from simpler components; central to understanding development from cells to minds.

concepts.name: Confabulation
concepts.context: Construction of narratives or understandings without direct evidence; normal part of intelligence development in both humans and AI systems.

concepts.name: Individuality
concepts.context: Property of cells as agents with problem-solving competencies; partially erased by bioelectrical networks that promote collective cooperation.

concepts.name: Cooperation
concepts.context: Coordination of cellular agents toward shared organismal goals; enables emergence of higher-order intelligence and resilience.

concepts.name: Cancer
concepts.context: Cells that disconnect from memory networks and pursue individual goals; emerging therapies aim to reconnect rather than kill defecting cells.

concepts.name: Cyborg
concepts.context: Hybrid beings combining biological and technological components; increasingly prevalent form from cochlear implants to language model hybrids.

concepts.name: Neuroprosthetics
concepts.context: Engineered neural enhancements enabling novel cognitive modes, sensory abilities, and mind-to-mind connectivity.

concepts.name: Sentient Beings
concepts.context: Entities capable of experiencing suffering and deserving moral consideration; proposed to exist across diverse embodiments beyond humans.

concepts.name: Relational Heuristics
concepts.context: Defensible frameworks for ethical relating to diverse intelligences based on shared capacities rather than origin stories.

concepts.name: Continuum Of Possible Minds
concepts.context: Understanding that minds exist on spectrum of possibilities rather than discrete categories; challenges outdated natural/artificial distinctions.

concepts.name: Bottom-Up Control
concepts.context: Mechanism of control based on molecular and genetic regulation; contrasted with higher-level story-based control of development.

concepts.name: Objectophelia
concepts.context: Misplaced relationship with objects that appear mind-full but lack genuine agency; risk in relating to sophisticated AI systems.

concepts.name: Large Language Models
concepts.context: Current AI architectures trained on human creative output; described as chimeras lacking biological self-construction processes for agency.

concepts.name: Dissociative Identity Disorder
concepts.context: Referenced in context of questions about identity that arise with advanced AI; whether different aspects of intelligence constitute unified selves.

concepts.name: Synthbiosis
concepts.context: Quest to develop mutually beneficial relationships between radically different beings evolving together at different rates; central vision for human-AI futures.

frameworks.name: Diverse Intelligence Framework
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Systematic approach to recognizing and relating ethically to intelligence across diverse embodiments from molecular to organismal scales.

frameworks.name: Cellular Collective Intelligence Research Program
frameworks.creator: Michael Levin
frameworks.context: Interdisciplinary investigation spanning philosophy of mind, evolution, and regenerative medicine to understand problem-solving in non-neural biological systems.

institutions.name: Tufts University
institutions.context: Home institution of Michael Levin; location of Allen Discovery Center researching diverse forms of intelligence and regeneration.

institutions.name: Allen Discovery Center at Tufts
institutions.context: Directed by Michael Levin; focuses on understanding intelligence scaling and regenerative biology.

institutions.name: Wyss Institute for Bioinspired Engineering
institutions.context: Harvard University institute where Michael Levin is associate faculty; combines biology and engineering approaches.

institutions.name: Harvard University
institutions.context: Home of Wyss Institute where Michael Levin conducts research on bioinspired approaches to intelligence and engineering.

institutions.name: Noema Magazine
institutions.context: Publication venue for this essay exploring philosophical and practical implications of AI development.

questions.question: How can we ensure that new generations of beings align with our values?
questions.context: Fundamental problem extending from child-rearing to AI development; requires understanding value transmission across diverse intelligences.

questions.question: How do we ensure that our creations treat themselves and us with kindness and compassion?
questions.context: Core ethical concern for both human offspring and artificial intelligences; depends on recognizing moral worth in diverse beings.

questions.question: How do we calibrate relationships with those who are not like us?
questions.context: Practical challenge as intelligence diversifies; requires moving beyond anthropocentric frameworks.

questions.question: What happens to us, and to humanity, if each generation becomes smarter and more adventurous than their parents?
questions.context: Addresses species-level continuity paradox and identity questions posed by rapid intelligence development.

questions.question: How exactly do we determine which of our creations have true understanding, responsibility and moral worth?
questions.context: Central philosophical challenge given that all intelligence obeys same laws of physics; requires new frameworks beyond current categories.

questions.question: What other bodies and minds can be made by cells and cell-technology?
questions.context: Open research question about diversity of possible intelligences and embodiments.

questions.question: What does it mean for a biological human to truly understand?
questions.context: Challenge to critics of AI understanding; requires definition of human understanding before judging AI deficiency.

questions.question: What skills and properties are essential to our humanity, and which are we willing to give up?
questions.context: Practical question about technological integration and human identity as enhancement technologies emerge.

questions.question: What really do we want to verify about AI-created content: its origin or its quality?
questions.context: Challenges focus on authenticity over value; questions whether origin-based judgments reflect xenophobia rather than rational criteria.

questions.question: Who do we want to be edged out by?
questions.context: Reframes existential anxiety about AI from defensive to aspirational; asks what future intelligences we actively want to create.

questions.question: What should the future of intelligence look like?
questions.context: Foundational question for species maturation; requires moving beyond dystopian fears to affirmative visions.

questions.question: How can we develop a principled continuum of ethical synthbiosis?
questions.context: Practical challenge for coexistence of diverse intelligences; requires frameworks transcending natural/artificial and us/them divisions.

questions.question: How do we scale our consciousness to essential qualities of being across diverse embodiments?
questions.context: Meta-question about expanding moral and cognitive frameworks to recognize kin in novel forms.
